comments.commentBody: 21 trillion.

Ronnie you bring up an interesting point. Why just breast and ovarian cancer? Well, women have always been an easy target for medical manipulation......Follow the money. Surgery done on: young women, low litigious risk, an endless supply of breasts and ovaries/uterus'....what more could a surgeon hope for. The Human Genome Project was started at 1989 and the only 'casualties' of this project have been the removal of healthy female sex organs....Are we surprised...No. women are an easy target, men are not. More men die of prostate cancer than ALL female gynecologic cancers combined, but men with genetic mutations will be assured that their prostate cancer will be caught early and they will not die from it. Women on the other hand will be strongly encouraged to be desexualized and any hope of surveillance will be downplayed. I would like to see a celebrity who has this mutation who actively engages and promotes healthy living and stringent surveillance, keeping us all updated on any non-surgical, non-radiating, non-toxic treatment options.....We have pumped billions of dollars into breast and other cancer research. I would like to think it got us more than......To rid the world of breast cancer, lets just rid the world of BREASTS...A 5 year old could have figured that out and probably would have done so for the price of a ice cream cone. This surgery saddens me.

shaun,
Do you have references for your percentage risk of only 5% for breast cancer? According to the article,
"Women who carry BRCA mutations have, on average, about a 65 percent risk of eventually developing breast cancer, as opposed to a risk of about 12 percent for most women."

Why are your statistics so divergent from the authors'?

Heather in Charlotte, I call the pain clinic that my father goes to his dealer. He has never been drug tested, and he's never been refused, whether it's oxycontin or hydracodone or both.  His spine doctor says he should have no pain.  Honestly, he's been taking the narcotics for knee pain--you know, the same knee pain that millions of people have.  Pain clinics do not weed out addicts nor adequately monitor.
This is true about the insurance coverage; however, (too) many women cannot financially afford the "luxury" of insurance in the first place.

I read somewhere that many companies (United Healthcare in the example I read about) makes you prove (documents required) that there is a multi-generational history of breast/ovarian cancer before they will pay for the test.

Good luck to refugees, adoptees, or those just not that close to their dead relatives.

Yes, and I'm sure Ms Dowd fully realizes that. But it is indeed true that the many of out there who are uninsured cannot afford to drop the $3K it costs to get tested, and Angelina could indeed help make that issue more public, and help "fight the fight" for those less fortunate than she is.

While we all laud her world charity, there is much that she could do HERE. There are many people HERE who live in abject poverty, granted, not conditions that mimic African villages, but still.

I often wonder where all these lefty celebrities are in the fight over income inequality HERE, at home? Are they not so vocal as they're wanting to save their own high incomes from that pesky tax man? One does wonder sometimes...
It might interest Ms. Dowd to learn that the sort of tests that were performed on Ms. Jolie are often covered by mediical insurance for those women who are in that same high-risk genetic.category

I read Joel's comment and looked at the piece mentioned. My mouth popped open, and indeed the aritcle was written by both Paul and Robin. It was great.

But why did that 2012 piece get buried in the NY Review of Book. The attacks on R & R don't do much good and those documented with Europe are not even convincing.

Why hasn't the argument of the 2012 piece been hammered and documented with the US data? A Princeton Democrat, Blinder, can say in the WSJ today that Simpson and Bowles called for $4 trillion in 2010 and that it has ALREADY been enacted. Now that is an austerity program. All Krugman has to do is combine that with per capita GDP, wiith consumption per capita by income,and with wage data by income.

Who cares about jobs or GDP except those who really care only about profits? The sales of S & P were apparently flat in the first quarter , but GDP and profits were up. The stock market naturally soared. And demand?

Obama has clearly decided to retire during his second term. He has passed Simpson-Bowles and has doubled the market. And even a Krugman won't criticize him. It is time for Krugman to talk to prospective 2016.candidates.

The National Enquirer is interesting not only abut Obama, but also about Hillary if it is right about her memoirs. If it is right, she surely has decided not to run. If so, it will be an interesting race. If she runs, is Krugman really going to support 4 more years of Rubin and Geithner?
Actually, this article is very appropriate. "Well that wont happen" is an ill-informed guess.
Estelle, please see other earlier comments made earlier. A plant based diet and exercise is no guarantee. Others have done so and still died.

I felt every word you wrote and oh how I'd love to meet your TCM practitioner!

Thank you for "do everything you can not to join the breast cancer industrial-complex". I am now four years older than my mother was in 1976, when she lost the will to go on following a mastectomy, a hysterectomy, and countless metastases. Was it an early ectopic surgery, or years of dyeing her hair? The hairdresser developed Alzheimer's at 40, so who knows.

After years of operations and radiation, and a final nine months in a hospital bed, my mother's death certificate simply states, toxic shock.

With each medical form, I had to enumerate my mother's cancers, and always greeted by the “high risk” threat. I was repeatedly advised a hysterectomy and oophorectomy. My intense fear of pain saved me from all that.

The more I learned about medical industrial complexes, the louder I got in the annual mammogram as the nurses dutifully, relentlessly crushed my poor breasts. When I was briefly insured I asked for a thermogram, but was denied.

I am vegan: other beings dislike pain as I do, and everyone wants to live. I eat organic because it just makes sense, and I have no doubt the World Famous Hospital Monster would have infected you with more cancer.

Thank you for your story, which reaffirmed all I intuited by my mother's deathbed, dissociating, in pain too great for either words or tears.

I hope you are well and happy and healthy and wish for you a very long and fruitful and gratifying life.

After a mastectomy that may have partially been caused by excessive mammograms, I had the healthy breast removed because the standard of care called for yet more mammograms and the needle biopsies that go with them. I'd already had erroneous mammograms, didn't want any more.

If I could do it over: Thermograms instead of mammograms; a pesticide-free mostly vegan diet (pesticides and animal products are estrogenic in a woman's body, and my lumpy, dense breasts were an early sign of estrogen dominance); protecting my liver so it could better clear estrogen from my body; no underwire bras; no brown hair dye. And, boy, I should have listened to my Traditional Chinese Medicine doctor who said I couldn't leave the clusters of micro-calcifications in my breast and she could get rid of them. (Don't laugh--she cured my asthma.)

Do everything you can not to join the breast cancer industrial-complex where you'll meet monsters like the head of breast surgery at a world-famous East Coast hospital. He connived to break my will and let him perform what he called a areola-sparing "experimental" mastectomy with implant. (I was determined to find and eventually got an autologous reconstruction using fat from my buttock, at the time a cutting-edge operation.) Had I buckled under to Dr. World Famous Hospital, I would have arisen from his table with a diagnosis of 3a lymph-node invasive cancer, which is what I had, and remaining aerola tissue ripe for cancer. Monsters, I tell you.

Treatments for cancer (radiation and chemo) are very toxic. Cancer cells that survive chemo will become resistant and cannot be killed by future rounds, and radiation is itself a cause of cancer. Much better to prevent it if you can, and keep you immune system from the "necessary" poisons of chemo and radiation.

Where did you get that information about ovarian cancer?

It is very, very unusual for a patient post mastectomy to not have either breast implants or reconstructive breast surgery.  There is no comparison between an outpatient breast enlargement  (done for cosmetic purposes) and reconstructive implants after a mastectomy. It is ridiculous to think "bigger and better breast" were part of the equation for Ms. Jolie.  A bilateral mastectomy is not 'a walk in the park' , it is major surgery.
Wrong, wrong, wrong Shaun. Please read the comments of the female M.D. above. It is 87%.

Your response to Jolie's choice to go public with this private information strikes me as callous and mean.

Yes, it was brave of her to take this option, and brave again for her to tell others about it in the hope of raising awareness.

Many people who go bald from chemotherapy opt to wear wigs. Does that show a lack of confidence, by your reasoning, or make them any less brave?
Daniel's trajectory and commitment to creating artistic documentation of Guatemala is unprecedented. His photos are to be wept over, treasured, and celebrated. abrazos enormes from a big fan.

Spectacularly artful images.

No comparison with David Bailey and David Hemmings in "Blowup"?

Or - "frugality" might do the trick too? -

And this time - please - "frugality" for the "greedsters" and the "gamblers" - who absolutely love them - some "technical" discussions - because they like to focus on the sole question "how to make some dough" - AGAIN!.

Now let's try to find a way - where they loose and "the people" win!!

"We will drink no wine before it's time" Need I say more?

Howie

TJ,

Do you forget the large percentage of the US population that does not have health insurance or that is under-insured? And the copays that are required even for the well-insured Choices is right--a small fortune that women might not be able to raise the funds for so that they go into all kinds of debt to cover what their insurance does not or what their non-existent insurance does not, I. e. all of it.

Dr. Swietaraski, we need more caring doctors like you.  Overprescription of narcotics can kill.  As for the person who swears that nothing else will work, I've watched one of these people, minus the cigarettes and with full, responsible employment, descend into addiction because doctors weren't alert to the fact that he was scamming and relatives enabled him.
At least you aren't an addict now.  The doctor and pain clinic did you a favor.

I used alternative medicine for years to try and stave off chronic kidney disease. I'm mighty grateful to Western medicine for inventing dialysis machines. I opted to have a transplant for quality of life purposes, knowing the health risks posed by immune supressants. But without Western medicine, I would have been dead years ago.
Karin, you have utterly missed the point. This is NOT just a marketing issue; this is about women's lives.
Andy Kaufman died of breast cancer, if I'm not mistaken.
